Unstable PST and CPST results, but I would say those are false unstable results. Avalanches are unlikely on that old NSF layer and stability is good. The NSF layer does not have a widespread distribution and has not produced recent avalanches. CPST 31/100 end
Surprised by lack of activity in the area. Many slopes nearby well tested by sled and snow bike, with only small CF and Dry Loose activity observed.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: No significant weak layers in upper 165 cm of snowpack. Interface at base of new storm layer shows gradual increase in density and bonding with underlying snow. Slightly softer snow 85 cm below surface may be buried NSF (rounding). DDL facets and crust very present at this location, 165 cm below surface. Skiing throughout the north-facing chute demonstrated a stable snowpack. Unclear if this shot may have slid on the Feb. 5 cycle. HASTY HAND PIT DUG BELOW CRUST AT 65 CM SHOWING MOSTLY FACETED SNOW WITH INTERLACED CRUSTS (PROFILE ESTIMATED).

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: SH 22 feb har facetterat, delvis bägarliknande kristaller./Johan

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Recent activity on similar slopes; Recent activity on different slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown face at ridgetop and wind loaded which is why the layers are so hard. The faceted layer on which this failed was much softer and more evident in a pit lower and on an adjacent slope.

Snowpit dug in below treeline terrain to compare results to previous observation on buried facet layer. Instability on the buried facet layer was limited with snowpack tests which was an improvement from past observations in this same area. 2x ECTX specific to buried facet layer at 146cm.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent activity on different slopes; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Some wind, decreasing during the day. Expected to pick up again in the afternoon. Clear blue skies, cold temperatures, signs of recent heavy wind. Windloading in all leeformations, hard windslab on top of the surface, in some areas easy to penetrate and signs of propagation when windslabs break.

We skied slope; Poor pit location
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Poor pit location due to rocks and shrubs in lower layer, which acted as trigger points in tests. Pit depth was also 2-3 times deeper then the rest of Telemark slide.
ALP. Läsluttning. Stenig mark. Sondade vidare genom K-hård snö ända till nära mark där det var mjukt igen. Liknande över hela sluttningen.

Pit_Observation.activities: Cracking; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pretty good stability. ~80 cm of new snow on mid February crusts

Pit_Observation.activities: Snowmobile tracks on slope; We snowmobiled slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug in three places. This is the only one that produced an ECTP. Others have similar layers but must have been stronger. We dug at 9000ft on ENE and at 8800 ft on NNW. Neither spot even produced ECTN's under the dust layers. However, we spotted one natural avalanche and know of another in the area. The one we spotted seemed to be a similar depth as the weak layer in this pit.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank; Recent activity on similar slopes; Recent activity on different slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: NWAC Incident Investigation for 2/25/18 avalanche occurrence with 2 fatalities. Profile west of flank on convex roll - difficult to access highest crown. Avalanche initiated in steep cliffy terrain along summer trail route to Snow Lake Divide at approx. 4235ft, 350ft wide, 500vertical, crown depth to 85cm. (SS-U-R3-D2.5-I)

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: other; Cracking; Recent activity on similar slopes
